text: Are there any good Julia resources or guides for biology? I am kinda stumped. Thanks in advance <3

elements.text: Are there any good Julia resources or guides for biology? I am kinda stumped. Thanks in advance <3

text: I mean, it really depends on what kind of biology. But in general, the docs for the packages you're interested in, plus asking questions here and on discourse (if, for example, you're not sure which packages you need) are probably the best places to start

text: I am new to julia. I am not sure where to start and I was planning to learn julia packages for bioinformatics.

elements.text: is a good introduction to biomodeling. And there's a few other bio talks in the symposium.

text:
"Bioinformatics" is just so broad. Are you doing modeling as Chris suggests? Are you doing human genomics, viral epidemiology, evolution, ecology?

Or are you unsure and just want to do something? If the later, I'd recommend working on some problems at <http://rosalind.info|rosalind.info> and then ask for help when you get stuck :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I came from Humans of Julia Discord and a member there and I are planning to write a project on BLAST written in julia or a package for viral epidemiology. I am quite to new to all of this since I started learning Python last year and just got introduced to Julia and doing code problems in <http://exercism.io|exercism.io>. We are planning to write a project because I think a project can help us learn more.
